# median { #dumbpy.median }

`median`

dumbpy.median
=============

Compute the median of numeric values.

The input may be a nested iterable; nesting is flattened via
:func:`dumbpy.support_functions.validate_list`.

## Functions

| Name | Description |
| --- | --- |
| [median](#dumbpy.median.median) | Compute the median of numeric values. |

### median { #dumbpy.median.median }

```python
median.median(values)
```

Compute the median of numeric values.

#### Parameters {.doc-section .doc-section-parameters}

| Name   | Type            | Description                                             | Default    |
|--------|-----------------|---------------------------------------------------------|------------|
| values | Iterable\[Any\] | A (possibly nested) iterable containing numeric values. | _required_ |

#### Returns {.doc-section .doc-section-returns}

| Name   | Type             | Description                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                 |
|--------|------------------|-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|        | Numeric \| float | The median value of the input after sorting. For odd-length inputs, the middle element is returned (so the type may be ``int``, ``float``, or ``bool``). For even-length inputs, the average of the two middle values is returned, which is typically a ``float`` (but can be an ``int``/``bool`` when the middle values are equal in this implementation). |

#### Raises {.doc-section .doc-section-raises}

| Name   | Type       | Description                                                                                                              |
|--------|------------|--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------|
|        | ValueError | If the flattened input contains no elements.                                                                             |
|        | TypeError  | If the input is not a valid iterable for flattening, or if any element is non-numeric (raised by :func:`validate_list`). |

#### Examples {.doc-section .doc-section-examples}

```python
>>> median([3, 1, 2])
2
>>> median([1, 2, 3, 4])
2.5
```
